Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Physics and Astronomy at Vanderbilt University
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of the Vanderbilt University Summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU), program, which offers undergraduate physics and astronomy students the opportunity to work closely with faculty on forefront research projects in a variety of subfields of physics. The areas include astronomy, biological physics, condensed matter physics including nanoscience, laser physics, nuclear physics, and particle physics. The extensive research infrastructure, including the facilities of several large interdisciplinary centers, will be available to the students. The Astronomy students will have opportunity for collaborative international research: they will take data and participate in exoplanets research with mentors at the South African Astronomical Observatory and at the Astrophysics Research Centre at Queen's University Belfast. They may also take data at the SMARTS facilities in Cerro Tololo, Chile. Physics students will have the opportunity to visit major facilities at government laboratories, both domestic and international, including FermiLab, Brookhaven, Oak Ridge, and CERN. The program is designed to build community among the students and the participating faculty as well as expose the students broadly to many areas of forefront physics and astronomy. Students are also offered the opportunity for training in the integration of research with education through the Fisk-Vanderbilt Physics & Astronomy Roadshow outreach program. The site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program and by the Office of International Science and Engineering within NSF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF funded Research and Education for Undergraduates in Physics and Astronomy program provides undergraduate students from throughout the country the opportinity to perform real, forefront research as a part of a funded research program in the  Department of Physics and Astronomy at Vanderbilt University. The subfields included are astronomy (observational and computational), materials/nano science (theoretical and experimental), nuclear/particle physics (theoretical and experimental), and biological physics (experimental). The program is held during the summer and lasts ten weeks. The students work closely with a faculty advisor and the postdocs and graduate students in their group. A goal of the program is to encourage the students to continue on to graduate school and to pursue a career in research. However, if a student decides otherwise, we do not consider this a failure. We have helped that student make a personal decision based on a real life experience.

A significant fraction of the students entering into research careers in the US are foreign students educated in the US. There is a distinct need for US students, particularly for classified research. In addition, physics and astronomy are two fields in which the fraction of the students receiving PhD's who are females or minorities is quite small. Vanderbilt University, through the Fisk/Vanderbilt Master's to PhD Bridge Program, is the number one producer of PhD's in physics and astronomy in the US. We recuit very proactively for women and minorities for the Bridge Program and, at the same time, for this REU program.

This grant has supported thirty three students to participate during the past three years. We were funded for thirty students. Of these students, 27% were female, 18% were Hispanic, 9% were African American, and 3% Native American, yeilding 36% minority. In addition, there have been twelve additional students who have participated in the program who were supported by supplements to individual NSF grants or directly by the NSF grant. Of these 42% were female and 33% were Hispanic. Overall, the program was 40% female, 29% Hispanic, 9% African American, and 2% Native American, yielding 40% minority. We also believe that we should focus on recruiting students who do not come from Research I universities as their ability to participate in funded, forefront research is much more limited. For the students funded by this grant, 64% came from non-Research I schools.

In addition to the rearch work, we provide the students with an extensive program in professional development. Classes are offered in laboratory techniques, laboratory safety, introductory through advance computing, ethics of science, time management, applying to graduate school, choosing a graduate school, and studying for the GRE, both the general and subject matter tests. We also have Vanderbilt faculty and several visitors give talks on their science. We held a weekly informal conversation with the scientists meeting where a professor meets informally with the students at a coffee shop to discuss whatever the students wish. We organized a trip to the Oak Ridge National Laboratory where we visited the Spallation Neutron Source (SNS), the Nano-Science Center, the High Flux Isotope Reactor (HFIR), the National Supercomputing Center, and the Graphite Reactor, and a trip to the Rocket Museum at NASA, Huntsville.

We organize a canoe trip down the Harpeth River, and then have the students themselves, with staff help, organize at least one social event each week. The students form a strong group of mutually supportive friends. We are very pleased that they rate this REU program as very enjoyable.

In summary, the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates in Physics and Astronomy at Vanderbilt University provides an intellectually challenging and enjoyable experience to some very talented young students by introducing them in a hands-on way to forefront research, with the goal of encourage them to consider continuing on to graduate school and pursuing a career in science research.
